reviewText: This is an old fashioned enjoyable yarn of the people who come together in the dying days of a grand old hotel in New Orleans, set during the early civil rights movement.  It is fun soap opera, starring Rod Taylor as the earnest, honest man who runs the hotel for his kindly, aging but behind the times boss.  The hotel is under threat of being bought out by the owner of a chain of hotels who wants to turn the elegant St. Gregory into another link in the chain.  Of course, he has a lovely, unhappy young mistress who takes to Taylor.  The other principals are the wonderful Michael Rennie as an English duke, haunted by a tragedy and the superb and still beautiful Merle Oberon as his ambitious, scheming wife, Karl Malden as comic relief as a hotel thief, lots of jazz and glimpses of the French Quarter.  Racial politics of the time thread through: the kindly old hotel owner will not desegregate his hotel, despite Taylor's awareness that this must be done.  The film dodges the issue of whether Taylor's character believes this is the moral or simply pragmatic thing to do; one senses it is the former, but while the film touches on this issue, it doesn't honestly handle it.I am a Rod Taylor fan, which is one of the reasons I enjoy this film.  Rennie and Oberon also make it worth watching.  So don't expect much, but if you enjoy B level dramas from that era, this is a pleasant one.  There is very little action, but the character takes seem to carry the tale along.
summary: For fans of Taylor, Rennie and Oberon

reviewText: Based on Arthur Hailey`s book of the same name, it is a pleasant enough film.  We follow the lives of the staff and a number of the guests.  Rod Taylor is the very efficient Hotel Manager, Merle Oberon the Duchess and Michael Rennie her husband, the Duke.  My favourite was Karl Malden as the thief who showed us a number of ways in which he got keys to rooms other than his own!Set in New Orleans we see some lovely parts of the old city.  The leading lady was European actrss Catherine Spaak.  Very attractive but I don`t think she made a lot of American films.A nice film but not a world beater.

reviewText: Hotel is one of my favourite Arthur Hailey Stories.  I bought the Video of this movie years ago. Now happy to get in in DVD as I move away from VCR usage very soon.I think this movie was typical historically of the time in America where there was still reluctance from some, then;  to de-segregate in employment or even accommodation of Afro Americans, in Hotels and so on.It was also an insight to corruption that still exists with in the Hospitality industry today.All the actors especially our very own Aussie Robert Taylor were great.Wish we could get more Arthur Hailey Movies on DVD, not just this one and Airport.

reviewText: What we have here, is an outstanding gathering of characters during one weekend or week in a famous old-school hotel down in Louisiana.  Watching the film, one feels as if the director and his crew basically went into a hotel and started filming real life people working and staying at a hotel.  But deep underneath this generalization, the director shows -the good, the bad, and the less meaningful types of people that surround us in everyday life-...

reviewText: I had to order this movie because when I first saw it years ago, I remember falling in love with Rod Taylor. Released in the '60's, this movie tells a saga of the lives of several who stay at a very special hotel, Rod Taylor being the absolute professional who runs the hotel. Good human interest, romance, intrigue. The theme song and music in this movie is first class. The actors in this movie present nothing less than top quality performances.If this movie was made today, the ending wouldn't be so clean...another reason for me to enjoy it.

reviewText: I read the book Hotel a few month's before watching the movie. I wish the movies story line followed the book's storyline a bit closer. There were two key characters in the book eliminated from the movie. One was Peter Mc Dermant's love intrest, who also worked at the hotel. The other was an old man who was a guest that becomes ill and has to remain at the hotel during his recovery (Dr's orders), despite not having any money to pay his bills.The elevator accident was down played to the point only one person died in the accident. The Dtchess's didn't have here dogs in the movie.The Doctor' convention storyline was completely cut out of the movie and the storyline of not letting a black couple stay at the hotel was completely different. I didn't care for the way they ended the movie. Its like there was no end and room was left for a sequel. The book ends in a completely different manner, quite a surprise twist. I'd recommend reading the book first. It was quite good and was a bit more on the comedic side too.The audio - visual quality of the DVD was fine.

reviewText: There are two reason why I like this movie.  First and foremost, I've been a big fan of Rod Taylor ever since "The Time Machine".  I've also been a big fan of Arthur Hailey, on who's novel this movie is based.  All of the characters slip into their roles and wear them well.  Melvin Douglas as the crotchety southern inn keeper who has pretty much turned the running of the St. Gregory Hotel over to his General Manager, played by Taylor.  The vindictive Hotel Mogul play by Kevin McCarthy, there to try to buy the St. Gregory to turn it into a tourist trap, his French Gal Pal, played by Catherine Spaak, who falls for Taylors character and one my favorites, Karl Malden as the hotel thief.  You would think that a movie about an aging New Orleans hotel would drag and have slow spots, but this movie keeps the pace going and is very watchable.  The quintessential 1967 car chase is replace in this movie by a hotel elevator rescue, and a laundry shoot escape by the hotel thief.  A very enjoyable movie.

reviewText: Again, the DVD archivists at Warner have done it again!  As they did with "Atlantis, The Lost Continent", this so-called 1:85 anamorphic aspect ratio is, in reality, a cropped (top and bottom) 1:33 aspect ratio from the VHS print!  I have the VHS, from which I compared the two images - the DVD is definitely cropped from a 1:33 aspect ratio.  Warner, why oh why can't you just do the right thing?  In any event, I am keeping the VHS copy as it is only cropped on the sides and not the top and bottom as well.

reviewerName: S. D. liddell-jones "kid in the fourth row"
reviewText: I'm moving and giving up my VHS plyer, having got most of my favorite flicks on discs.  But I won't give it up if it means never seeing "Hotel" again. It sets such a mood; puts you right into the hotel and the era.Almost everything about it is perfect, and what isn't, is campy.(like the decor of the hotel lobby) Rod Taylor is one of the sexiest men ever to hit the screen, i agree that while C. Spaak is gorgeous and classy,and a good actress; her spine is not straight, she looks kind of deformed about the shoulder area, and i guess no effort was made to hide it, but she's still lovely.  I love the score, it has just the right haunting quality, and each character has his own theme. Larger-than-life, as always, Kevin McCarthy nearly steals the show, as the heavy. And that heartbreaking moment when Merle Oberon tries to pretend that her husband had died still loving her.I cry every time. And the icing on the cake; the ever wonderful Michael Rennie, who always makes "the earth stand still" for me! I could go on raving, but why NO DVD????!!!! This is a classic; let's get with it!!!!  LJ
summary: where's the DVD for this GEM of a movie?

reviewText: As Judith Crist called "Airport" upon its release in 1970, "the best film of 1944," 1967's "Hotel" also based on a novel by Arthur Hailey, is indeed old-fashioned in its presentation.  The best-seller it was based on, in a style called an "omnibus" probably dates back even before the sensation of 1932's "Grand Hotel" wherein a cast of big name actors play inhabitants involved in the machinations of a bigger entity providing even more drama to its latest catastrophe.  With "Airport" it heralded the advent of the disaster film which usually utilized this same plot construction.  Involved in 1967's "Hotel" are Rod Taylor, Catherine Spaak, Merle Oberon, Kevin McCarthy, Melvyn Douglas, Karl Malden, Richard Conte and Michael Rennie, but there is a more slight catastrophe, the oncoming closing of the hotel due to changing times and possibly its demolition.  Directed by Richard Quine who also brought us "How to Murder Your Wife" and "Synanon" handled it well and the screenplay by Wendell Mayes was also very good, as usual (he wrote the scripts for Otto Preminger's "Anatomy of a Murder," "Advise and Consent" and "In Harm's Way," all the deftly handled scripting of a bestselling book).  The original score by Johnny Keating is very beautiful  and haunting in a somewhat conventional style as well, featuring the songs "This Year" and the theme from "Hotel" both of which are sung by Carmen MacRae (who is featured in the film), although I was dismayed she did not sing the theme for "Hotel" in the film (see my review of the soundtrack CD).  Catherine Spaak is one of those odd happenings why she was considered a sex bomb starlet in the sixties, mostly in European imports like Roger Vadim's "The Circle of Love" (here in the U.S., but "La Ronde" (the re-make) in Europe); "The Empty Canvas" and "The Little Nuns"), but she did cross into U.S. films in things like "Hotel" and "Weekend at Dunkirk."  Today she is probably best known for the female lead in Dario Argento's "Cat o Nine Tails."  Rod Taylor was never sexier (which he could be, surprisingly) and it featured one of the last roles Merle Oberon had before retiring her supreme beauty from our sights.  In some reviews, Karl Malden is claimed to be a scene stealer, but I found him to be humorous, but lacking the guile of evil-intent to play a criminal as the hotel thief, so I thought he was somewhat mis-cast.  But the film is rather sumptuous, as the beautiful color, beautifully transferred by Warner Archive here, the decor, the music all begin to unravel for an entertaining viewing.  Critics also said Hailey's plot mechanics were re-hashes of old plots as there is nothing really new here as there was to come in "Airport."  But it is worth it to get a another glimpse of how it was done to breathe life on the screen as only Hollywood used to.
summary: Preceded "Airport," Old-fashioned, but Not as Good
